default: (a) a {@item shield|PHB} or (b) any {@filter simple weapon|items|source=phb|type=simple weapon=sand|category=basic}
(a) a {@item component pouch|PHB} or (b) an {@item arcane focus|PHB} or {@item druidic focus|PHB}
(a) a {@item explorer's pack|PHB} or (b) an {@item dungeoneer's pack|PHB}
(a) a {@item shield|XPHB} or (b) any {@filter simple weapon|items|source=phb|type=simple weapon=sand|category=basic}
(a) a {@item component pouch|XPHB} or (b) an {@item arcane focus|XPHB} or {@item druidic focus|XPHB}
(a) a {@item explorer's pack|XPHB} or (b) an {@item dungeoneer's pack|XPHB}

fluff.name: Shaman
entries: Nature is a powerful force containing a myriad of mysterious magics. Shamans have the ability - learned, intuited, or innate - to act as a conduit for that natural magic.
Shamans channel ancient rites in the form of runes, summon elemental spirits, and evoke powerful elemental magic to manipulate their enemies and allies alike.

entries.name: Creating a Shaman
entries: To create a Shaman, consult the subsections which give you hit points, proficiencies, and starting equipment. Then look at the Shaman table to see which features you get at each level. The descriptions of those features appear below.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a Shaman quickly with these suggestions: First, put your highest ability score in Wisdom, followed by Constitution or Dexterity; second, choose the Outlander background; third, choose the {@spell Produce Flame|XPHB} and {@spell Dancing Lights|XPHB} cantrips, along with the 1st-level {@spell Ice Knife|XGE} and {@spell Thunderwave|XPHB} spells.

entries.name: Multiclassing and the Shaman
entries: If your group uses the optional rule on multiclassing in the Player's Handbook, here's what you need to know if you choose Shaman as one of your classes.

entries.name: Ability Score Minimum
entries: As a multiclass character, you must have at least a Wisdom score of 13 to take a level in this class, or to take a level in another class if you are already a Shaman.

entries.name: Proficiencies Gained
entries: If Shaman isn't your initial class, here are the proficiencies you gain when you take your first level as a Shaman: light armor and simple weapons.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: To determine your available spell slots, you include all of your Shaman levels.

classFeature.name: Optional Rule: Alternate Ability Hunter
entries: Hunters usually rely on their instincts, governed by Wisdom, their awareness of the world around them. But you may prefer that your Hunter gains an advantage through their wit and quick thinking, or their unbreakable resolve fueling their efforts.
If this is the case for your Hunter, you may prefer to use Intelligence or Charisma instead of Wisdom for your Hunter features. If you do so, make the following changes:

items: Features which specify your Wisdom modifier (such as Supreme Quarry) instead use the modifier of the chosen ability.
Your Hunter DC is calculated with that ability, instead of Wisdom.

classFeature.name: Instinct
entries: Hunters rely on their senses and instincts. You can apply yours more keenly than most creatures, granting you an edge in combat that you can exploit in various ways. Your Instinct recovers on a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}.

You also have a Hunter's Die, which determines the damage or bonus granted by some of your features. You have an amount of Instinct equal to your Hunter level (as indicated in the Hunter Table) and additional equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum 0).

classFeature.name: Quarry
entries: A Hunter needs a target. Once per turn, you can spend one Instinct and a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to designate a creature within 60 feet of you as your Quarry, the target of your hunt. The designation lasts for up to one hour, and when you hit that creature with an attack, you deal additional damage equal to your Hunter's Die of the same type as your weapon. You can have only one Quarry at a time.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: Your skills as a warrior are commendable, and you gain a {@filter Fighting Style Feat|feats|category=FS} of your choice.
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace that Fighting Style feat with another.

classFeature.name: Survival Instincts
entries: A gut instinct guides your senses. Whenever you make an ability check using {@skill Perception|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB}, you can spend one Instinct to add your Hunter's Die to the roll total.

classFeature.name: Tricks
entries: A Hunter is flexible, able to adapt their skillset to most threats. These Tricks are combat techniques, unique skills or benefits to your skills, or modifications to your defenses. They may be informed by your Hunting Grounds.

At 2nd level, you know 2 {@filter Tricks|optionalfeatures|feature type=HTR}, and learn more as indicated in the Tricks column of the Hunter table. Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can change one Trick for another that you qualify for, represented by your preparations for the day ahead.

If a Trick has prerequisites, you must meet them to gain that Trick. You can gain a Trick at the same time you meet its prerequisites. A level prerequisite refers to your level in this class. If you lose the prerequisite for a Trick, for example you change one Trick that another depends on, you may replace it with another Trick for which you meet the prerequisite.

If a Trick grants or modifies an attack you cannot use more than one at a time. For example, if you use the Retaliate trick to strike back at a foe, you cannot use the Trip Attack Trick on that reliatory strike.
If a Trick requires a saving throw, the DC is equal to 8 plus your Strength or Dexterity modifier plus your Proficiency Bonus.

classFeature.name: Shrug It Off
entries: It takes a significant hit to phase you. You can spend one Instinct and a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to roll your Hunter's Die, add your Wisdom modifier, and gain Temporary Hit Points equal to the total.

classFeature.name: Keen Eye
entries: When you make an attack roll against your Quarry, you can spend one Instinct to add your Hunter's Die to the roll.

classFeature.name: Hunting Grounds
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you distinguish yourself from other Hunters by calling on the skills developed in your Hunting Grounds, the place you honed your skills. Your Hunting Grounds grant you features at 3rd level, and again at 7th, 11th, and 15th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Hunter levels 8, 12, and 16.

classFeature.name: Lesser Quarry
entries: Choose one of the following benefits. When you designate your Quarry, you gain that benefit.

entries.name: Relentless
entries: Your Quarry cannot {@condition Frighten} you.

entries.name: Cautious
entries: Your Quarry cannot {@condition Charm} you.

entries.name: Strategic
entries: You learn your Quarry's resistances, vulnerabilities or immunities to any damage or conditions.

classFeature.name: Offensive Hunter
entries: At 6th level, your skill as a Hunter have grown and you develop new techniques to fell larger foes or to cleave through their minions. Choose one of the following:

entries.name: Focused Assault
entries: You deal an additional {@dice 1d4} damage on attacks against a creature that is below its maximum hit points.

entries.name: Considered Strikes
entries: You score a critical hit on attacks when rolling a 19 or 20 on the {@dice d20}. Whenever you roll a critical hit, you deal additional damage equal to one roll of your Hunter's Die.

entries.name: Thin the Herd
entries: Once on each of your turns when you attack a creature, you can immediately make another attack against a different creature within 10 feet of the target that is within your reach or range.

classFeature.name: Sixth Sense
entries: You can mark your Quarry without being able to see them. You have advantage on any Wisdom or Intelligence checks made to find your Quarry or see through its illusions, and your quarry lasts up to eight hours.

classFeature.name: Hunting Grounds Feature
entries: When you reach 7th level, you gain another feature from your Hunting Grounds.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Hunter levels 12 and 16.

classFeature.name: Greater Quarry
entries: Choose one of the following benefits. When you designate your Quarry, you gain that benefit.

entries.name: Relentless
entries: When you hit your Quarry with an attack, its AC is reduced by 3 until the end of your turn.

entries.name: Cautious
entries: When your Quarry deals damage to you with an effect that targets only you, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to halve the damage you take from that effect.

entries.name: Strategic
entries: When you attack your Quarry, you can instead end the Quarry and make an attack against every other creature of your choice within your reach (if you use a melee weapon), or within 10 feet of your quarry (if you use a ranged weapon).

classFeature.name: Defensive Hunter
entries: At 10th level, your skill as a Hunter have grown further and you develop new techniques to help you evade danger. Choose one of the following:

entries.name: Quickstep
entries: Creatures cannot make opportunity attacks against you.

entries.name: Pattern Recognition
entries: After a creature hits you with an attack, you gain a +4 bonus to your {@variantrule Armour Class|XPHB|AC} against all other attacks made by that creature until the end of its turn.

entries.name: Evasion
entries: When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

classFeature.name: Hunting Grounds Feature
entries: When you reach 11th level, you gain another feature from your Hunting Grounds.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement feat or another feat of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Hunter level 16.

classFeature.name: Superior Quarry
entries: Choose one of the following benefits. When you designate your Quarry, you gain that benefit.

entries.name: Relentless
entries: Your attacks against your Quarry deal additional damage equal to your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Cautious
entries: You have an additional 5 feet of reach when attempting to attack your Quarry with a melee weapon. If you use a ranged weapon, you do not suffer disadvantage on attacks outside of the weapon's normal range that are made against your Quarry.

entries.name: Strategic
entries: After your Quarry makes an attack roll, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to impose a penalty to the roll equal to your Hunter's Die. At the additional cost of one Instinct, you can do this when your Quarry makes a saving throw.

classFeature.name: Refined Instincts
entries: You gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws, and one of your choice of Charisma or Intelligence saving throws.

classFeature.name: Hunting Grounds Feature
entries: When you reach 15th level, you gain another feature from your Hunting Grounds.

classFeature.name: Supernatural Hunter
entries: Your skills as a Hunter grow again, to the extent that your abilities seem almost supernatural. Choose one of the following abilities, which you can use once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}:

entries.name: Vanish
entries: You can spend a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to become {@condition Invisible|XPHB} until the end of your next turn. While invisible, you can pass through objects and creatures that you otherwise couldn't as if they were {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. If you end your turn within an object or creature's space, you take 3d10 force damage and are shunted to the nearest available space.

entries.name: Blur
entries: You double your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} this turn (no action required). The first time you take damage after this turn, any unspent movement is used to reduce that damage, spending 1 feet of unused movement for every 1 point of damage.

entries.name: Reaper
entries: As an {@variantrule Action|XPHB}, you can make a special attack which, if it kills a creature, allows you to make another attack. All of these attacks deal additional damage equal to your Hunter's Die.

classFeature.name: Supreme Quarry
entries: Choose one of the following benefits. When you designate your Quarry, you gain that benefit.

entries.name: Relentless
entries: You have advantage on attacks against your Quarry.

entries.name: Cautious
entries: You have advantage on any saving throws you make against your Quarry and its effects.

entries.name: Strategic
entries: You force your Quarry's attention, protecting your allies. The first time each turn your Quarry targets one of your allies, your Quarry has disadvantage on its attack (if it attacks), that ally has resistance to any damage dealt and advantage on any saving throws it makes.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain an {@filter Epic Boon Feat|feats|category=EB} or another {@filter feat|feats|} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Hunter's Zenith
entries: Your Wisdom score increases by 2, and so does your Strength or Dexterity score (you choose), both up to a maximum of 30.

You can have up to two creatures as your Quarry at any one time, and when you mark one you can mark another at no cost. Choosing another Quarry only ends your previous Quarry if you would have more than two, in which case you choose which to end.
At this level, you also gain access to a unique and powerful Trick: Relentless, Cautious, or Strategic Hunter.

classFeature.name: Optional Rule: Alternate Ability Shaman
entries: While Shamans channel nature's magic in a similar mystical manner to druids, it is also possible to learn this power through study, or through force of will in dedication to nature.
If this is the case for your Shaman, you may prefer to use Intelligence or Charisma instead of Wisdom for your shaman features. If you do so, make the following changes:

items: Wherever you would use Wisdom for your shaman features or specialism features, such as your Spellcasting or Rune features, you instead use your chosen ability.
If you choose Intelligence, you replace Charisma as a saving throw proficiency given by this class with Intelligence.
A multiclassed character would require a 13 in the chosen ability (instead of Wisdom) to take a level in this class, or take a level in another if Shaman is your first class.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: Your experience in nature has infused you with the primordial magics of the world. This could be a life in a tribe, time spent wandering the wilds and finding a spirit, or unexpected communion with a nature deity. Whatever its origin, it fuels your spellcasting. You can channel these primal magics to strike those who would defy nature, restore your allies, and manipulate the world around you.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know two cantrips of your choice from the Shaman spell list. You learn an additional cantrip of your choice at 7th level.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Shaman table above shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter shaman spells|spells|class=Shaman} of 1st-level or higher. To cast one, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all of your expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the shaman spell list.
You learn an additional Shaman spell of your choice every level, and every other level from level 11 onwards.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the Shaman spells you know and replace it with another spell from the Shaman spell list, which must also be a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for Shaman spells as you draw magic from your connection to nature. You use your Wisdom when a Shaman spell refers to your spellcasting ability, and you use your Wisdom modifier whenever you set the saving throw DC or make a spell attack roll for one of your Shaman spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item druidic focus|XPHB} as a spellcasting focus for your shaman spells. You or your DM may decide it more appropriate to use an {@item arcane focus|XPHB}, depending on how your shaman learned their magic.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: Your connection to nature can be channeled with time, at less cost to yourself. You can cast a shaman spell you know as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag.

classFeature.name: Elemental Affinity
entries: At 1st level, your attunement to nature grants you an affinity with a specific element. Choose one of the following:

entries.name: Affinity with Flame
entries: Your chosen element is fire. You gain the {@spell Firebolt|XPHB} or {@spell Green-Flame Blade|TCE} cantrip. Additionally, you gain the {@b Growing Heat} feature below.

entries.name: Growing Heat
entries: Whenever you deal fire damage to a creature, they take additional damage equal to your proficiency bonus whenever you deal fire damage to them before the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Affinity with Frost
entries: Your chosen element is cold. You gain the {@spell Ray of Frost|XPHB} or {@spell Frostbite|XGE} cantrip. Additionally, you gain the {@b Biting cold} feature below.

entries.name: Biting Cold
entries: Once per round, when you deal cold damage to a creature, that creature suffers a penalty equal to your proficiency bonus to the next attack roll or ability check that it makes before the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Affinity with Lightning
entries: Your chosen element is lightning. You gain the {@spell Crackling Bolt|J:General} or {@spell Shocking Grasp|XPHB} cantrip. Additionally, you gain the {@b Arc Lightning} feature below.

entries.name: Arc Lightning
entries: Once per round, when you deal lightning damage to a creature, you can arc lightning from one target to another. Up to two different creatures of your choice within 15 feet of the original target take Lightning damage equal to your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Affinity with Thunder
entries: Your chosen element is thunder. You gain the {@spell Thunderclap|XGE} or {@spell Booming Blade|TCE} cantrip. Additionally, you gain the {@b Thundercrack} feature below.

entries.name: Thundercrack
entries: Once per turn, when you deal Thunder damage to a creature, you may move it five feet in a direction of your choice, provided it is large or smaller. Additionally, whenever you deal thunder damage to an object, you maximise the value of the dice instead of rolling damage against that object.

entries.name: Affinity with Acid
entries: Your chosen element is acid. You gain the {@spell Acid Splash|XPHB} or {@spell Primal Savagery|XGE} cantrip. Additionally, you gain the {@b Persistent Corrosion} feature below.

entries.name: Persistent Corrosion
entries: When you deal acid damage to a creature, you can cause the acid to linger on them. At the start of each of its turns, the creature takes acid damage equal to your proficiency bonus. The acid lasts until a creature uses its action to remove it, or you use this feature again on a different target.
You can change your elemental affinity whenever you gain a level in this class.

classFeature.name: Primordial Runes
entries: Your access to the primal forces of the world has granted you access to Primordial Runes, fragments of primal spirits which can enhance your own power, grant you new abilities or allow you to conjure totems which grant benefits within an area.

At 2nd level, you gain 2 Primordial Runes of your choice. A list of the available options can be found on the {@filter Optional Features|optionalfeatures|feature type=PRU} page. When you gain certain Shaman levels, you gain additional runes of your choice, as shown in the Runes column of the Shaman table.
Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the runes you know and replace it with another that you could learn at that level.

If a rune has prerequisites, you must meet them to gain that rune. You can gain a rune at the same time you meet its prerequisites. A level prerequisite refers to your level in this class. If you lose the prerequisite for a rune, for example you change your elemental affinity, you may replace it with another rune for which you meet the prerequisite.

classFeature.name: Elemental Origin
entries: At 3rd level, you determine the origin of your shaman abilities. This could be the source that they are drawn from, where your Shaman grew up or learned their magic, or the specific location they first unlocked their magical gifts.
This origin grants you features at 3rd level, and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th level.

classFeature.name: Elemental Origin Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your elemental origin.

classFeature.name: Elemental Affinity Improvement
entries: At 7th level, your attunement to the elements grows deeper. You become resistant to the damage type of your chosen elemental affinity.

classFeature.name: Primordial Knowledge
entries: Your strong connection to nature allows you access to ancient knowledge and abilities.

items: You gain a bonus to {@skill arcana} and {@skill nature} checks equal to your spellcasting ability modifier.
Additionally, you learn the {@spell Skill Empowerment|XGE} spell and can cast it once per long rest without expending a spell slot. It does not count against the number of Shaman spells you know.

classFeature.name: Elemental Origin Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your elemental origin.

classFeature.name: Elemental Origin Feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your elemental origin.

classFeature.name: Elemental Affinity Improvement
entries: At 17th level, you are a paragon of your chosen element. You become immune to the damage type of your chosen elemental affinity.

classFeature.name: Overload
entries: At 18th level, you gain the ability to briefly push your magical abilities to their limit by experiencing magical feedback.
When you cast a Shaman spell, you can deal the maximum possible damage instead of rolling on the turn that you cast it.
Upon doing so, you take force damage equal to your Shaman level plus the level of the spell cast, which cannot be reduced in any way, and you cannot cast spells until after your next turn.
After you use this ability, you cannot do so again until you complete a short or long rest.

classFeature.name: Spiritual Avatar
entries: At 20th level, you can use a bonus action to channel the spirits of nature directly for one minute, using yourself as a conduit. This might change your appearance as you choose to suit your elemental affinity or origin, such as your head being lit with flames, or your skin being covered with frost.
While this state is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: You gain a flying speed of 50 feet.
Whenever you cast a Shaman spell that has a casting time of one action, you can cast it using a bonus action instead.

entries: At this level, you also have access to a Primordial Rune specific to your subclass that can enhance your Spiritual Avatar in another way.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you complete a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Edge of the World
entries: Borderland Hunters walk on the borders of the Material Plane and its mirror, the Feywilds, stalking the creatures that live there. Living in shades of grey and dim light, they have mastered the borders and can briefly change where they reside, striking terror no matter where a creature escapes to.

subclassFeature.name: Skills from the Borderland
entries: {@i 3rd-level Borderland Hunter feature}
Your experience in dealing with creatures of the between-realm has given you skills related to reading intention and concealing your own.
You gain proficiency with two of the following skills: {@skill Insight|XPHB}, {@skill Deception|XPHB}, {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}, or {@skill Arcana|XPHB}.
Additionally, you gain proficiency with {@item Navigator's tools|XPHB} and {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}, so you are never lost, and can identify the dangerous flora of the feywilds.

subclassFeature.name: Border-world Quarries
entries: {@i 3rd-level Borderland Hunter feature}
Ghosts don't have bodies, and fey are tricksy. Try the fancy fire.
When you damage your Quarry, you can choose for the additional damage dealt by your Hunter's Die to be Radiant damage.

subclassFeature.name: Ethereal Shift
entries: {@i 3rd-level Borderland Hunter feature}

You can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to shift into a state between the planes. While in this state, which lasts for one minute, you can move through other creatures freely. If you move through a creature this way, they take necrotic damage equal to a roll of your Hunter's Die. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.
If you end your turn in another creature's space, you are shunted harmlessly to the nearest available space. Ethereal Shift ends if you become {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} or die.
You can use this feature for free once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, otherwise it costs 2 Instinct.

subclassFeature.name: Expert
entries: {@i 7th-level Borderland Hunter feature}

The skills you gained from the Borderlands have improved. You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} in the skills you chose, and one of the tools from, your {@subclassFeature Skills from the Borderland|Hunter|Starlight|Borderland|Starlight|3|Starlight|Skills from the Borderland} feature.

subclassFeature.name: Ethereal Shift Improvement
entries: {@i 7th-level Borderland Hunter feature}
While using Ethereal Shift, you can cast Misty Step once on each of your turns (no spell slot required).

subclassFeature.name: Fae Tricks
entries: {@i 11th-level Borderland Hunter feature}

When a creature hits you with an attack, spell, or other effect while you are using Ethereal Shift, you can use a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to end Ethereal Shift and teleport up to 30 feet away, potentially causing the effect to miss.
Regardless of if you evade the effect, the attacking creature must make a Wisdom saving throw or take {@dice 4d8} psychic damage. This damage increases to {@dice 5d10} at level 15.

subclassFeature.name: Grave Step
entries: {@i 15th-level Borderland Hunter feature}
While using Ethereal Shift, you have {@sense Truesight|XPHB} out to a range of 60 feet.

Additionally, the necrotic damage you deal by passing through a creature's space increases to two rolls of your Hunter's Die. When you cast Misty Step using Ethereal Shift, you can deal this damage to all creatures in a 5-foot line between the space you teleport from and your destination.

subclassFeature.name: Planeswalker
entries: Extraplanar Hunters walk the outer planes, dealing with Celestials, Demons and Aberrations alike. Time spent in these outer regions inevitably grants a taste of the power these creatures wield, which Extraplanar Hunters manipulate to their own end. They may protect other planes from these creatures, go on missions in these areas, or simply live their lives there.

subclassFeature.name: Skills from the Outer Planes
entries: {@i 3rd-level Extraplanar Hunter feature}
Your experience in the outer planes has taught you much about magic and the beliefs and mythologies of others.
You gain proficiency with 2 of the following skills: {@skill Arcana|XPHB}, {@skill Religion|XPHB}, {@skill Insight}, or {@skill Persuasion}.

Additionally, you gain proficiency with any {@item Gaming Set|XPHB} and {@item Cook's Utensils}, as some creatures from these planes are known to enjoy games, and their food may not be to your liking.

subclassFeature.name: Outer-planes Quarries
entries: {@i 3rd-level Extraplanar Hunter feature}
You gotta deal with a wide range of creatures in the outer planes, nothing works against all of them. So try to hit it where it hurts: right between the eyes.
When you damage your Quarry, you can choose for the additional damage dealt by your Hunter's Die to be Psychic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Planar Gift
entries: {@i 3rd-level Extraplanar Hunter feature}

Your exposure to otherworldly magics has given you access to a pool of energy you can derive power from. It can hold a number of your Hunter's Die equal to your Proficiency Bonus and refills when you complete a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. Damaging your Quarry adds one Hunter's Die to the pool.

subclassFeature.name: Aberrant Ward
entries: {@i 3rd-level Extraplanar Hunter feature}

Pulling from the Psionic Powers of Aberrations, you can protect your allies. When an ally within 30 feet of you takes damage, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to roll any number of dice from your Planar Gift, reducing the damage they take by the total rolled.

subclassFeature.name: Expert
entries: {@i 7th-level Extraplanar Hunter feature}

The skills you gained from the outer planes have improved. You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} in the skills you chose, and one of the tools from, your {@subclassFeature Skills from the Outer Planes|Hunter|Starlight|Urban|Starlight|3|Starlight|Skills from the Outer Planes feature}.

subclassFeature.name: Celestial Dusting
entries: {@i 7th-level Extraplanar Hunter feature}
When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can spend and roll one die from your Planar Gift to grant that many temporary hit points to yourself or a creature within 10 feet of you.
If you damage your Quarry, you can instead use the Hunter's Die rolled as part of the attack.

subclassFeature.name: Infernal Edge
entries: {@i 11th-level Extraplanar Hunter feature}

Once per turn, you can use a die from your Planar Gift to attempt to poison a creature when you hit them with a weapon attack. The target must make a Constitution saving throw or become {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} until the end of your next turn, and take necrotic damage equal to a roll of the Planar Gift die. They take half as much damage on a successful save.

subclassFeature.name: Planar Boon
entries: {@i 15th-level Extraplanar Hunter feature}
Your gifts from the outer planes have grown in power:

items: Aberrant Ward now pushes the attacking creature 10 feet away from the ally you protect with it.
Celestial Dusting can also be used to restore hit points to a creature, and its range is 30 feet.
Infernal Edge imposes disadvantage on the saving throw if your target is a Fiend, Celestial or Aberration.

subclassFeature.name: Bounty Hunter
entries: Those who hunt in this environment have a unique challenge. Finding one creature in a crowd, instead of a forest. Vertical, cramped terrain, with winding alleys and hidden paths. And a thousand places to disappear in plain sight. Urban Hunters cut through this noise, finding their marks and stopping them from getting away - if they ever saw you in the first place.

subclassFeature.name: Skills from the City
entries: {@i 3rd-level Urban Hunter feature}
Your experience navigating the cities has taught you how to find secrets, and how to get your way.
You gain proficiency with two of the following three skills: {@skill Investigation|XPHB}, {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}, and {@skill Intimidation|XPHB}.
Additionally, you gain proficiency with {@item Forgery Kit|XPHB|Forgery Kits} and {@item Thieve's Tools}, to help you gain access to well-guarded places.

subclassFeature.name: Everyman Quarries
entries: {@i 3rd-level Urban Hunter feature}
Poison isn't what it used to be, and if you're a good soul you'll be hunting assassins yourself. It's a rare citygoer who can resist something like this, though.
When you damage your Quarry, you can choose for the additional damage dealt by your Hunter's Die to be Necrotic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Crippling Attack
entries: {@i 3rd-level Urban Hunter feature}
The best way to hunt a creature is to prevent them getting away in the first place.

As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can spend one Instinct to make a special attack against a target. On hit, they take damage equal to your Hunter's Die and must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, they are {@condition Slowed|Starlight}. On a successful save, they are {@condition Hampered|Starlight} instead.

subclassFeature.name: Expert
entries: {@i 7th-level Urban Hunter feature}

Your city-life skills have improved. You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} in the skills you chose, and one of the tools from, your {@subclassFeature Skills from the City|Hunter|Starlight|Urban|Starlight|3|Starlight|Skills from the City} feature.

subclassFeature.name: Seeker
entries: {@i 7th-level Urban Hunter feature}

You have a knack for finding people. You can spend one Instinct and an Action to sense the direction to a creature as per the {@spell Locate Creature|XPHB} spell. This lasts for ten minutes and does not require your {@status concentration|concentrating}.

subclassFeature.name: Silent Killer
entries: {@i 11th-level Urban Hunter feature}
You can take the {@action Hide|XPHB} action as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

While unseen by a creature, you can make a special attack against it as an {@variantrule Action|XPHB}. On hit, the target must make an Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition Silenced|Starlight} and {@condition Deafened|XPHB} until the start of your next turn, and they take additional damage equal to your Hunter's Die.

subclassFeature.name: Opportunist
entries: {@i 15th-level Urban Hunter feature}
When you kill a creature, you become {@condition Invisible} until the start of your next turn. This invisibility ends if you make an attack or force another creature to make a saving throw.
Your Silent Killer special attack can be used in place of an attack, instead of as an {@variantrule Action|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Beast Hunter
entries: Horizon Hunters strive to be the best, hunting anything from sky to sea. They weaken their quarries in speed in strength, claim trophies from their strikes and even have the expertise to handle packs of creatures. They might do it for fame and fortune, they might do it to protect the innocent from the dangers of the wild, or they might simply hunt for the thrill of bettering themselves.

subclassFeature.name: Skills from the Wilds
entries: {@i 3rd-level Horizon Hunter feature}
In order to hunt beasts, you must travel far and learn how to cope with animals of all temperaments and sizes.
You gain proficiency with two of the following three skills: {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB}, {@skill Athletics|XPHB}, and {@skill Survival|XPHB}.
Additionally, you gain proficiency with piloting air or water vehicles, and with a {@item Navigator's Kit|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Bestial Quarries
entries: {@i 3rd-level Horizon Hunter feature}
If you must slay beasts, I don't know a beast alive that's a fan of fire. Hopefully by the time you find one you can work your way around that.
When you damage your Quarry, you can choose for the additional damage dealt by your Hunter's Die to be Fire damage.

subclassFeature.name: Declaw
entries: {@i 3rd-level Horizon Hunter feature}

You can attempt to cripple your Quarry. Once per turn when you make a successful attack with the {@variantrule Attack|XPHB|Attack action} against your Quarry, you can spend one Instinct to force it to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, you can disable one of its attacks until the start of your next turn. If you forgo dealing damage, it has disadvantage on the saving throw.

subclassFeature.name: Trophies
entries: {@i 3rd-level Horizon Hunter feature}

When you roll a 20 on an attack roll against your Quarry, it drops a trophy, an item of significance such as a serpent's venomous fang. You can sell a Trophy in your downtime for 10gp times the creature's CR. At your DM's discretion, you may require a Wisdom (Survival) check and 1d4 days to find a suitable buyer - in these cases, the item may sell for more.

subclassFeature.name: Expert
entries: {@i 7th-level Horizon Hunter feature}

Your skills from the wild have improved. You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} in the skills you chose, and one of the tools from, your {@subclassFeature Skills from the Wilds|Hunter|Starlight|Urban|Starlight|3|Starlight|Skills from the Wilds} feature.

subclassFeature.name: Roaming
entries: {@i 7th-level Horizon Hunter feature}
Your walking speed increases by 10 feet, and you gain a Climb and Swim speed equal to your walking speed.
You can hold your breath underwater for an additional number of minutes equal to your Wisdom modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Pack Hunting
entries: {@i 7th-level Horizon Hunter feature}

When your Quarry dies, you can designate another creature of the same type as your Quarry immediately (no action required). The first time you do this each {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, it costs no Instinct. Any other time, it costs one Instinct.

subclassFeature.name: Siphon Speed
entries: {@i 11th-level Horizon Hunter feature}

Once per turn when you hit a creature with an attack, you can deal extra damage equal to your Hunter's Die and force it to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed saving throw, if the creature has a flying, burrowing, swimming, or climbing speed, that speed is reduced by half until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Apex Hunter
entries: {@i 15th-level Horizon Hunter feature}
When a creature fails their saving throw against Siphon Speed, your movement speeds are replaced with theirs until the start of your next turn, unless yours are higher.
When you hit your Quarry, its immunities are treated as resistance, and you bypass its resistances.

subclassFeature.name: Storyteller
entries: Fable Hunters gained their knowledge from study, and almost all of them have a common goal: to be a Hunter that would be discussed in the very books and tales they learned from. A Fable Hunter aims to live forever, immortalised in stories told around a fireplace and studies of combat strategy. A Fable Hunter wants to take on creatures of Legendary power; and a Fable Hunter wants to win. To this end, they learn their foe, and direct their allies to victory. Success comes before personal glory.

subclassFeature.name: Skills of Yore
entries: {@i 3rd-level Fable Hunter feature}
For your tale to be told, you must develop the quick wits and knowledge to tell it.
You gain proficiency with two of the following skills: {@skill Perception|XPHB}, {@skill Nature|XPHB}, and {@skill Performance|XPHB}.
Additionally, you gain proficiency with {@item Smith's Tools|XPHB} and {@item Woodcarver's Tools}, to keep your group well-supplied.

subclassFeature.name: Epic Quarries
entries: {@i 3rd-level Fable Hunter feature}
The toughest creatures earned their rep', and they come in all shapes and sizes. Getting past defenses like that is tricky for even the strongest mages... but you might have a way.
When you damage your Quarry, you can choose for the additional damage dealt by your Hunter's Die to be Force damage.

subclassFeature.name: Commander
entries: {@i 3rd-level Fable Hunter feature}

Whenever you make an attack with the {@action Attack|XPHB} action, you can instead spend one Instinct to command an ally. The ally you choose can use their {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to move up to their {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}, or make an attack against your Quarry. The attack has a bonus to the damage roll equal to a roll of your Hunter's Die.

subclassFeature.name: Expert
entries: {@i 7th-level Fable Hunter feature}

Your story-making skills have grown. You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} in the skills you chose, and one of the tools from, from your {@subclassFeature Skills of Yore|Hunter|Starlight|Urban|Starlight|3|Starlight|} feature.

subclassFeature.name: Rally
entries: {@i 7th-level Fable Hunter feature}

Whenever you make an attack with the {@action Attack|XPHB} action, you can instead spend one Instinct to inspire a friendly creature within 60 feet of you. That creature gains temporary hit points equal to a roll of your Hunter's Die plus your Wisdom modifier, and their next successful attack deals additional damage equal to your Hunter's Die.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter's Call
entries: {@i 11th-level Fable Hunter feature}

Once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, you can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} and one Instinct to mark one target with a special Quarry. Whenever any creature hits the target with an attack, the target takes damage equal to your Hunter's Die. At the start of your next turn, the Quarry ends.

subclassFeature.name: Commanding Shout
entries: {@i 15th-level Fable Hunter feature}

Once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, you can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to imbue your allies with epic tenacity. Until the end of your next turn, allies within 30 feet of you cannot be reduced below one hit point or killed, their {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} cannot be reduced, and they cannot be {@condition Stunned|XPHB} or {@condition Restrained|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Legendary Resilience
entries: {@i 15th-level Fable Hunter feature}

When you are targeted by a Legendary Action (and similar actions such as Mythic Actions), you can either gain advantage on a saving throw you a forced to make, or gain resistance to any damage dealt by it.

subclassFeature.name: Waters
entries: Water is often described as the source of life. Shamans of the waters - be that rivers, lakes, or the sea - know this, and control water in order to control life itself. They can manipulate the flow of positive energies in order to manipulate the flow of battle. Using water's restorative magic to assist their allies, and the force of water to throw their enemies off-balance.

subclassFeature.name: Waters Shaman Spells
entries: {@i 3rd-level Waters Shaman feature}
You always know these spells from the table below once you reach certain levels in this class. You cannot swap these spells out on level up, unlike your normal Shaman spells.

entries.caption: Waters Shaman Spells
rows: {@spell Freedom of Movement|XPHB}, {@spell Aura of Purity|XPHB}

subclassFeature.name: Meandering Streams
entries: {@i 3rd-level Waters Shaman feature}

Water supplies life in all places, and water flows down mountains and across plains before reaching the sea. This intuitive knowledge of the wider world and its layout grants you proficiency with the {@skill Survival} skill and {@item cartographer's tools|XPHB}. It would also be reasonable to have waterproof paper or a waterproof pouch to keep your supplies in.
Additionally, you can hold your breath for twice as long as you otherwise could.

subclassFeature.name: Ebb and Flow
entries: {@i 3rd-level Waters Shaman feature}

When you restore hit points to a creature, you can use an action or a bonus action to throw a jet of water at an opponent within 30 feet. Make a ranged spell attack: on a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d4} bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition Off-balance|Starlight}.

subclassFeature.name: Ebb and Flow Improvement
entries: {@i 6th-level Waters Shaman feature}
The damage of the water jet increases to {@damage 2d4} + your Wisdom modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Flow As Water
entries: {@i 10th-level Waters Shaman feature}
You can breathe underwater and gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

Furthermore, when a creature hits you with an attack, you can use a reaction to transform briefly into water and move up to your movement speed in any direction without provoking opportunity attacks, and gaining the {@condition Regenerating|Starlight} condition with an amount equal to your Shaman level, for one turn.

This movement can move through other creatures' spaces, but if you end your movement in another creature's space you are ejected to the nearest unoccupied space, taking {@damage 1d8} force damage for each 5 feet you are ejected.
You can use this reaction once per short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Master of the Tides
entries: {@i 14th-level Waters Shaman feature}
Your Ebb and Flow has improved to match the very motion of the world itself, in the model of the ocean's tides.

When your water jet hits a target, you can restore hit points equal to the damage dealt to a creature of your choice within 30 feet of the target. The damage of the water jet increases to {@damage 2d8} + your wisdom modifier.
Finally, you can use the water jet without needing to restore hit points to a creature.

subclassFeature.name: Mountains
entries: The mountains are steadfast and towering, watching over the world and earth while being unmovable by any convential means. Shamans of the Mountains inhabit these places, settling on or within the mountains, moving stone, guarding themselves and others, and attuning to nature so as to carry out its will. They are stoic, often living introverted lives in small communities, but do valuable work in maintaining the balance of nature in the harsh climates of the mountains.

subclassFeature.name: Mountains Shaman Spells
entries: {@i 3rd-level Mountains Shaman feature}
You always know these spells from the table below once you reach certain levels in this class. You cannot swap these spells out on level up, unlike your normal Shaman spells.

subclassFeature.name: Mountain Home
entries: {@i 3rd-level Mountains Shaman feature}

The mountains have stood the test of time, and with that time comes knowledge. You gain proficiency in {@item mason's tools|XPHB} and have advantage on Intelligence checks made to identify information about or investigate the properties of rooms or objects comprised in some way of stone (for example, the history of a ruin, natural properties of mountains, investigating a stone room).

Furthermore, you count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift, and you are naturally adapted to cold climates when considering {@hazard extreme cold|DMG}.

subclassFeature.name: Mountainhide
entries: {@i 3rd-level Mountains Shaman feature}
Your skin is toughened by your elemental source. While you are not wearing armour, your AC is 13 plus your Constitution modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Unwavering Spirit
entries: {@i 3rd-level Mountains Shaman feature}
You can call on the spirits for active protection when you are in danger. When you take damage, you can use a reaction to reduce that damage by {@dice 1d6} plus your Constitution modifier.
You can do this a number of times per long rest equal to your proficiency bonus, or spend a spell slot of first level or higher to gain an additional use (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Earthly Attachments
entries: {@i 6th-level Mountains Shaman feature}

You are connected to the earth and ground, and all living things on them. When you see a creature within 30 feet of you take damage, you can channel your {@subclassFeature Unwavering Spirit|Shaman|Starlight|Mountains|Starlight|1|Starlight} to protect them instead of yourself, reducing the damage they take.
The damage reduction of your Unwavering Spirit is increased to {@dice 2d6} plus your Constitution modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Unwavering Spirit Improvement
entries: {@i 10th-level Mountains Shaman feature}

The mountains watch over vast swathes of land, as you do, and now your own magic becomes a source of this protection. The damage reduction from your {@subclassFeature Unwavering Spirit|Shaman|Starlight|Mountains|Starlight|1|Starlight} increases to {@dice 3d6} plus your Constitution modifier and your Wisdom modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit of the Valley
entries: {@i 10th-level Mountains Shaman feature}

You can call on the chilling winds of the valley. You can use an action to {@condition slowed|Starlight|slow} all creatures of your choice within 10 feet of you. Once you do, you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.
Your experience with mountainous terrain means that you are no longer affected by difficult terrain on surfaces made of stone or rocks, snow, ice, or similar ground.

subclassFeature.name: True Mettle
entries: {@i 14th-level Mountains Shaman feature}

You are a titan of endurance, a bastion for your allies. The damage reduction from your {@subclassFeature Unwavering Spirit|Shaman|Starlight|Mountains|Starlight|1|Starlight} increases to {@dice 4d6} plus your Constitution modifier and your Wisdom modifier.

Alternatively, you can now use your unwavering spirit to protect a creature from death. When the target would be reduced to 0 hit points as a result of taking damage, you can expend a reaction and use of your unwavering spirit to reduce it to 1 hit point instead.

subclassFeature.name: Watcher of the World
entries: {@i 14th-level Mountains Shaman feature}
You resist even entropy itself. You age ten times slower than similar creatures due to your elemental origin. Each decade that passes causes you to age only one year.

subclassFeature.name: Dunes
entries: The dunes are unforgiving environments - be they hot or cold - and discretion is often the better part of survival. Shamans of the Dunes often live nomadic lifestyles, roving the deserts and ensuring that even such a harsh environment can continue its intended course. They are often reclusive, living within their travelling group, but may forge strong bonds - any survivor knows that surviving is easier done with allies at your side.

subclassFeature.name: Dunes Shaman Spells
entries: {@i 3rd-level Dunes Shaman feature}
You always know these spells from the table below once you reach certain levels in this class. You cannot swap these spells out on level up, unlike your normal Shaman spells.

subclassFeature.name: Life in the Dunes
entries: {@i 3rd-level Dunes Shaman feature}

Survival in a desert is no easy feat. You must be able to make do with scant resources, and able to avoid the predators and dangers that roam - an upfront approach is rarely your best choice. You gain proficiency in {@item cook's utensils|XPHB} and {@skill Stealth}.
Furthermore, you are naturally acclimated to hot or cold temperatures (depending on your desert) when considering {@hazard extreme heat|DMG} or {@hazard extreme cold|DMG}.

subclassFeature.name: Mirage
entries: {@i 3rd-level Dunes Shaman feature}

You can channel the power of the changing temperatures in the desert to conjure mirages. When you are targeted by an attack or ability that targets an area (such as a dragon's breath or a {@spell fireball|XPHB|fireball spell}, you can use your reaction to teleport 5 feet to an unoccupied space in a direction of your choice, potentially avoiding the effect.

subclassFeature.name: Control the Storm
entries: {@i 6th-level Dunes Shaman feature}

Deserts are known for their harsh weather conditions, and you can create some of your own. Once per short rest, you can spend an action to create a storm of swirling particulates in a 15 foot radius around you (this could be snow or sand, for example). This area provides half cover for you and your allies and is difficult terrain for creatures other than you to move through.

subclassFeature.name: Duneswalker
entries: {@i 6th-level Dunes Shaman feature}
You are practised in walking the deserts, and are not affected by difficult terrain consisting of sand, snow, or other similar materials such as fine gravel.

subclassFeature.name: Superior Mirage
entries: {@i 10th-level Dunes Shaman feature}

Your mirage is superior, increasing the distance that it covers. You can teleport up to 10 feet when using your {@subclassFeature Mirage|Shaman|Starlight|Dunes|Starlight|1|Starlight|mirage}, and you can spend a spell slot of any level to increase the distance you teleport by a number of feet equal to 10 times the slot level expended.

subclassFeature.name: Liquefaction
entries: {@i 14th-level Dunes Shaman feature}

You have learned much greater control over the desert storms. You can {@status concentration||concentrate} on your {@subclassFeature Control the Storm|Shaman|Starlight|Dunes|Starlight|6|Starlight|storm} when you summon it to increase its power, granting the following benefits.

items: You can use a bonus action to move the storm independently of yourself, up to 20 feet, where the storm then remains until you move it again.
The area is lightly obscured. You and creatures you choose can attempt to hide in this light obscurement.

Hostile creatures entering the storm or starting their turn in it must make a Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 5d8} piercing damage and become {@condition blinded} until the start of their next turn.

entries: You can concentrate on the storm this way once per long rest. If you lose your {@status concentration}, the storm ends and you must complete a short rest to use it again, as normal.

subclassFeature.name: Forests
entries: Forests are a resilient environment, but are more vulnerable to explicit attack than many others. To this end, Shamans of the Forests take on the role of a hunter, personally handling those who would threaten the forests, be that its trees, inhabitants, or plantlife. The power of the forests grants pursuit, recovery and adaptability - Shamans living this way are open to new solutions, working together, and recovering from a setback.

subclassFeature.name: Forests Shaman Spells
entries: {@i 3rd-level Forests Shaman feature}
You always know these spells from the table below once you reach certain levels in this class. You cannot swap these spells out on level up, unlike your normal Shaman spells.

subclassFeature.name: Home in the Trees
entries: {@i 3rd-level Forests Shaman feature}

The rampant plant growth in a forested environment provides opportunity, but also cover. You are trained to see past that cover, and make use of plants and herbs available to you. You have proficiency with the {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB} and with the {@skill Perception} skill.
Furthermore, owing to your hunting training, you have proficiency with medium armour. You can choose to replace your starting Leather Armour with Scale Mail instead.

subclassFeature.name: Runeblade
entries: {@i 3rd-level Forests Shaman feature}

You can spend one minute to conjure a Runeblade, a weapon forged of primal magic and natural growth - it is as strong as a normal weapon but nonmagical. The weapon can be any with the finesse property, for example, a {@item dagger|XPHB}, {@item shortsword|XPHB}, {@item scimitar|XPHB}, {@item whip|XPHB} or {@item rapier|XPHB}. You determine its appearance, but it should take on the approximate physical qualities of the weapon you conjured; for example, a whip might be made of vines, or a shortsword from a bark cutting edge. If you conjure a second Runeblade, the first one withers and disappears to dust. You are considered Proficient with your Runeblade.

If you possess a magical weapon, you may spend an hour performing a primal ritual to connect with the weapon, which can be done as part of a short rest or attunement. The weapon becomes nonmagical, and your Runeblade takes on its magical properties when conjured. This connection lasts until you choose to end it or replace it with another magical weapon, at which point the magic returns to the original weapon.

subclassFeature.name: Runeblade Invocation
entries: {@i 3rd-level Forests Shaman feature}

You can use your primal magic to invoke the runes on your Runeblade. When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action, you can expend a spell slot of any level to cause the following effects to take place.

items: Your Runeblade deals {@damage 1d4} additional damage. The damage is equal to the weapon's type or, if you have the feature, the damage type of your {@classFeature Elemental Affinity|Shaman|Starlight|3|Starlight|elemental affinity} (you choose).
If you expend a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, your Runeblade attacks deal an additional 3 damage per slot level above first.
You activate one of your known Runeblade Invocations, detailed below.

entries: You can choose 3 of the following Runeblade powers to learn, and you learn an additional powers at 6th, 10th and 14th level in this class. When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one power with another from this feature. If a power has a level requirement, you must be at least that level in this class to learn it. If a power requires a saving throw, it uses your Shaman spell save DC. Powers last until the start of the following turn from their activation.

entries.name: Rapid Growth
entries: Your Runeblade has an additional 5ft of reach.

entries.name: Leeching Seed
entries: When you damage an enemy with your Runeblade, you regain hit points equal to the damage dealt by the attack (not including the additional damage from this feature).

entries.name: Deep Foliage
entries: You are surrounded by the leaves of the forest, granting you a +3 bonus to your AC and Dexterity saving throws.

entries.name: Gust Step
entries: Your movement speed is increased by 20 feet.

entries.name: Razorleaf Edge
entries: Your Runeblade attacks cause targets to {@condition Bleed|Starlight}.

entries.name: Erupting Vines (6th level or higher)
entries: The first time you hit a creature with your Runeblade this turn, it must make a Strength saving throw or become {@condition Restrained} until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Sporeburst (6th level or higher)
entries: Once, when you hit a creature with your Runeblade, you can force it to make a Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition Dazed|Starlight} until the end of its turn.

entries.name: Hunter's Instinct (10th level or higher)
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls with your Runeblade.

entries.name: Distracting Colouration (10th level or higher)
entries: Your attacks demand attention, or cow your opponents. The first creature you hit with your Runeblade is either {@condition charmed|XPHB} by you, or it has disadvantage to attack a creature other than you on its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: {@i 6th-level Forests Shaman feature}
When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action on your turn, you can attack twice with your Runeblade instead of once.

subclassFeature.name: Treeswalker
entries: {@i 6th-level Forests Shaman feature}
You are not affected by difficult terrain consisting of plants or similar foliage. If a plant is hazardous, such as being covered in spines, it does not harm you.
For you, the {@spell Plant Growth|XPHB} spell only requires you to spend 2 feet per 1 foot of movement.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Runeblade Invocation
entries: {@i 6th-level Forests Shaman feature}
You learn one additional Runeblade Invocation.

subclassFeature.name: Masterful Hunter
entries: {@i 10th-level Forests Shaman feature}
You can {@action Hide|XPHB} as a bonus action, and can attempt to do so when you are only lightly obscured. While hidden, your movement speed is increased by 15 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Runeblade Invocation
entries: {@i 10th-level Forests Shaman feature}
You learn one additional Runeblade Invocation.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Invocation
entries: {@i 14th-level Forests Shaman feature}

A number of times per day equal to your proficiency bonus, you can activate two effects simultaneously when you {@subclassFeature Runeblade Invocation|Shaman|Starlight|Forests|Starlight|1|Starlight|invoke your runeblade}.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Runeblade Invocation
entries: {@i 14th-level Forests Shaman feature}
You learn one additional Runeblade Invocation.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Guardian Angel
entries: As a reaction to a friendly creature within 30 feet of you taking damage, you can use your Channel Divinity to protect them, preventing the triggering damage and surrounding them in an invulnerable barrier which gives them resistance to all further damage.
If the protected creature makes an attack, casts a spell that affects an enemy, deals damage to another creature, or forces a creature to make a saving throw, the effect ends.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Rallying Cry
entries: As a bonus action, you hold your weapon or arm aloft and shout a rallying cry, beckoning your allies forward.

You can use your Channel Divinity to choose creatures you can see within 30 feet of you, up to a number equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one creature). Until the end of their next turn, each of those creatures gains a bonus to weapon attack and damage rolls equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one), and an additional 10 feet of movement speed.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed in the Oath of Unity Spells table.

entries.caption: Oath of Unity Spells
rows: {@spell Sanctuary}, {@spell Protection from Evil and Good}
{@spell Circle of Power}, {@spell Dispel Evil and Good}

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Unity
entries: The Oath of unity is a vow taken to protect the ideals of community and the people within it. They seek to protect the people from evil, as the selfish can never truly be united. This often extends to powers and beings from other planes, who would seek to take aspects of the material plane for their own. The imagery of a paladin under this oath may take the shape of wings, as a protector or guardian angel, working together to protect people from the horrors that would tear them and their kingdoms apart.

You may have received your calling during a moment of heroism, or a moment of vulnerability, in the service or protection of others. Or perhaps you heard a voice on the wind, under a full moon. However this oath came to you, you value the safety of others above all, and seek to put down selfishness in all its forms.

entries.name: Community
entries: The people need you. Be their shield.

entries.name: Courage
entries: Bravery is not the absence of fear, but acting in spite of it. Evil prevails when good men do not act - so you should act.

entries.name: Honour
entries: Be fair and just. Your actions are your deeds. Avoid harm, but do not let that get in the way of doing good.

entries.name: Tolerance
entries: Intolerance cannot be tolerated. People may exist as they are, unless they threaten the peace of others. To stay neutral is to side with the oppressor.

entries.name: Integrity
entries: You cannot be responsible for others if you cannot hold yourself to account. Protect those in your care, and ensure that all authority is just.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Coordination
entries: Beginning at 7th level, your presence provides inspiration to your allies, allowing you to coordinate their movements. Friendly creatures that start their turn 10 feet of you may take the Disengage action as a bonus action on that turn.

subclassFeature.name: Resilient Spirit
entries: Beginning at 15th level, your presence is a stronghold. Each friendly creature within your Aura of Coordination regains hit points equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1) at the start of each of their turns, to a total no higher than your paladin level.

subclassFeature.name: Champion of the People
entries: At 20th level, your presence becomes a terror to enemies who stand against you, and you become a beacon of hope to your allies. As an action, you transform, becoming a shining beacon of unity for your allies to rally around. You may be surrounded by swirling sigils and sparkling moonlight.
During the transformation, you gain the following features for ten minutes:

items: Your aura is filled with bright moonlight.
Your spirit is empowered: friendly creatures within your aura have advantage on wisdom saving throws, and regain the maximum health possible from any healing.

Your resolve is unbreakable: when a friendly creature would be reduced to zero hit points or killed within your aura, they are instead reduced to one hit point. A given creature can benefit from this only once per long rest.
Your form cannot be changed against your will.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Quick Reactions
entries: When you roll initiative, you can spend one Instinct to roll your Hunter's Die and add it to the total. You can do so after the roll.

optionalfeature.name: Hunter's Insight
entries: You have a knack for reading people and their intentions. You can spend one Instinct to add your Hunter's Die to any ability check you make using the {@skill Insight|XPHB} skill. You can do this after the roll, and if this turns the roll from a failure to a success, you regain the Instinct you spent.

optionalfeature.name: Heavy Training
entries: You gain proficiency with Heavy Armour.

optionalfeature.name: Trip Attack
entries: You can attempt to trip a creature when you attack it. You can spend one Instinct when you make an attack to force the target to make a Strength saving throw against your Hunter DC, falling {@condition Prone|XPHB} if it fails.

optionalfeature.name: Retaliate
entries: When a creature hits you with an attack, you can spend one Instinct and a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to make an attack against that creature, adding your Hunter's Die to the attack roll.

optionalfeature.name: Driving Strike
entries: When you hit a creature with an attack, you can spend one Instinct to force the target to make a Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 15 feet away from you.

optionalfeature.name: Dazzling Strike
entries: When you hit a creature with an attack, you can spend two Instinct to force the target to make a Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition Disoriented|Starlight}.

optionalfeature.name: Finder of Traps
entries: You can spend one Instinct and a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to sense the location and purpose of any traps (and their triggers) within 60 feet of you.
A trap is any object or mechanism that was created or placed to cause damage or other danger. This could include spells, physical mechanisms, or even dangerous loopholes in a contract.

optionalfeature.name: Trapsetter
entries: At the start of each day, you can improvise {@item Ball Bearings|XPHB}, {@item Caltrops|XPHB}, {@item Acid|XPHB} or {@item Oil|XPHB}. You can {@action Utilize|XPHB} this improvised item with a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} instead of replacing an attack or using the {@action Utilize|XPHB} action.
Once created, the item lasts for 24 hours or until you improvise another, which costs 10gp and takes ten minutes.

optionalfeature.name: Preparations
entries: You can plan ahead when you know what the day holds.

At the start of each day, you can prepare a number of special coatings equal to your Proficiency Bonus. These coatings provide a +1 bonus to attack rolls and deal 1d4 additional damage of a damage type of your choosing other than force or psychic.
You can apply these to an arrow or other weapon with no action cost, but only one can be used at a time. The coatings retain their potency for 24 hours or until used.

optionalfeature.name: Naturally Talented
entries: You gain proficiency in a Hunter skill you are not already proficient in (Athletics, Acrobatics, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Medicine, Nature, Perception, Stealth, Survival), then you gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} in one that you are proficient in.

optionalfeature.name: Trained in Darkness
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} out to a range of 60 feet. If you already have darkvision, its range is increased by 60 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Parry
entries: When you are hit by an attack, you can spend one Instinct and your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to reduce the damage by two rolls of your Hunter's Die plus your Wisdom modifier.

optionalfeature.name: Cleaving Attack
entries: When you hit a creature with an attack, you can spend two Instinct to make an additional attack against another creature within your reach. The damage of the attack is equal to a roll of your Hunter's Die plus your Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice), of the same type as the original weapon.

optionalfeature.name: Readied Strike
entries: When a creature enters your reach and you are holding a melee weapon, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to make an attack against them, adding your Hunter's Die to the attack roll.

optionalfeature.name: Environmental Conditioning
entries: Your exposure to a range of creatures and environments has taught you how to prepare for many a situation.
When you complete a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can choose to become resistant to one of fire, cold, acid, lightning or thunder damage.

optionalfeature.name: Superior Stamina I
entries: You can take the {@action Dash|XPHB} action as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Staggering Blow
entries: When you make an attack, you can spend one Instinct to attempt to impede your opponent's coordination.
On a hit, the target must make a Strength saving throw or be {@condition Staggered|S: Conditions} until the start of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Sundering Blow
entries: When you make an attack, you can spend one Instinct to attempt to temporarily weaken your opponent's armour.
On a hit, the target must make a Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition Sundered|S: Conditions} until the start of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Hampering Attack
entries: Your attacks are aimed such that they affect your opponent's movement. When you hit a creature with an attack, it becomes {@condition Hampered} until the start of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Pocket Sand
entries: Once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, you can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} and one Instinct to attempt to {@condition Blinded|XPHB|blind} a creature. Choose a creature within 5 feet of you. It must make a Constitution saving throw or become {@condition Blinded|XPHB} until the start of your next turn. You must have a free hand to use this Trick.

optionalfeature.name: Instinctual Mark
entries: You can mark a creature as your Quarry without using your {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, but it costs 2 Instinct to mark a creature in this way.

optionalfeature.name: Shrug it Off Improvement
entries: When you use Shrug It Off, you can roll an additional Hunter's Die when determining the Temporary Hit Points gained.
As part of that {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can choose to spend additional Instinct, rolling one additional Hunter's Die for each Instinct spent.
Finally, you can use Shrug It Off to recover Hit Points, instead of gaining Temporary Hit Points.

optionalfeature.name: Sterner Stuff I
entries: You have resistance to poison damage and advantage on any saving throws made against the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition.

optionalfeature.name: Indefatigable I
entries: You can remove one level of exhaustion whenever you complete a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Cunning Hunter I
entries: When you make a Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) or Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand|XPHB}) check, you can spend one Instinct to add your Hunter's Die to the total.

optionalfeature.name: Sliding Attack
entries: You are especially manoeuvrable. You can use two Instinct and an {@variantrule Action|XPHB} to do a special {@action Dash|XPHB} which allows you to move through other creature's spaces and not provoke opportunity attacks. Once per turn, if you move through a creature's space as part of this, you can make one attack with advantage against that creature.

optionalfeature.name: Power Attack
entries: When you make an attack against your Quarry, you can spend one Instinct to subtract your Proficiency Bonus from the attack roll, but add your Hunter's Die to the damage dealt if the attack hits.

optionalfeature.name: Powerful Stride I
entries: Your movement is not impeded by {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Superior Stamina II
entries: Your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} increases by 10 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Naturally Gifted
entries: You gain proficiency in a Hunter skill you are not already proficient in (Athletics, Acrobatics, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Medicine, Nature, Perception, Stealth, Survival), then you gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} in one that you are proficient in.

optionalfeature.name: Reputation Preceding
entries: You can spend one Instinct to add your Hunter's Die to an ability check that uses the {@skill Intimidation|XPHB}, {@skill Persuasion|XPHB} or {@skill Performance|XPHB} skills.

optionalfeature.name: Honed Senses
entries: You have additional Instinct equal to twice your Wisdom modifier, instead of once.

optionalfeature.name: Indefatigable II
entries: Once per turn when you regain hit points, including from rolling Hit Dice during a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, you can regain an additional amount equal to your Wisdom modifier.

optionalfeature.name: Powerful Stride II
entries: You gain the benefits of the {@spell Freedom of Movement|XPHB} spell whenever you are conscious.

optionalfeature.name: Disarming Strike
entries: When you hit a creature with an attack, you can spend one Instinct to force it to make a Strength saving throw or let go of or drop an object of your choice that it is holding. The object lands in the creature's space if possible.

optionalfeature.name: Sterner Stuff II
entries: You have advantage on any saving throw against necrotic damage or the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} or {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} conditions.

optionalfeature.name: Cunning Hunter II
entries: You are untraceable. You make no sound when Hiding and cannot be tracked or seen by Divination or other magic unless you choose to be.

optionalfeature.name: Hunter's Resilience
entries: Once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB} when you fail a saving throw, you can reroll it with a bonus equal to your Hunter's Die.

optionalfeature.name: Relentless Hunter
entries: Attacks you make against your Quarry bypass damage resistance, and treat damage immunity as resistance.

optionalfeature.name: Cautious Hunter
entries: When an effect would reduce you to zero hit points, you can spend a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} and one Instinct to be reduced to one instead. Then roll your Hunter's Die four times, add your Wisdom modifier, and regain hit points equal to the total rolled.

optionalfeature.name: Strategic Hunter
entries: If you have used your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, you can spend one Instinct to take another. You can use only one reaction per triggering event.

optionalfeature.name: Hunter of the Planes
entries: You are trained to protect yourself from supernatural effects. You cannot be possessed.
Additionally, you can spend 1 Instinct to reroll a saving throw against being {@condition Charmed|XPHB} or {@condition Frightened|XPHB}. You must use the new roll.

optionalfeature.name: Favoured Terrain: Outer Planes
entries: You feel most comfortable when things are strange. In environments on other planes, you have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) checks, you cannot become lost outside of magical means, {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} does not slow your travel, you can forage for food in any environment, and while tracking other creatures you can learn their number and when they last passed through the area.
Furthermore, you can spend one Instinct to roll your Hunter's Die to identify supernatural danger. If you roll 4 or higher, you learn if you are being watched and how.

optionalfeature.name: Supernatural Defenses
entries: Your exposure to creatures from other planes has taught you how to resist their powers. You become resistant to necrotic, radiant, and psychic damage.

optionalfeature.name: Banishing Strike
entries: When you hit an Aberration, Celestial or Fiend with an attack, you can attempt to drive them away. Once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, you can spend two Instinct to cast the {@spell Banishment|XPHB} spell on the target. Success or fail, the target takes additional damage equal to two rolls of your Hunter's Die.

optionalfeature.name: Attunement with the Planes
entries: Once per {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can cast the {@spell Plane Shift|XPHB} spell, targeting only the Upper or Lower planes, or the Material Plane. You do not require the material components.

optionalfeature.name: Hunter of Ghosts
entries: Borderland Hunters can pursue their foes even as they step into or through the Ethereal Plane. When you hit a creature with an attack, it cannot change the plane that it is on (for example, the {@spell Blink|XPHB} or {@spell Plane Shift|XPHB} spells) until the end of your next turn.
If you see a creature teleport, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to move up to your speed in pursuit of it.

optionalfeature.name: Favoured Terrain: Borderlands
entries: You are experienced travelling the lands that border your own. When travelling through the Ethereal Plane or the Feywilds, you have advantage on Wisdom (Survival) checks, you cannot become lost, {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} does not slow your travel, you can forage for food in any environment, and you have advantage on ability checks or saving throws made to see through illusions.
Furthermore, in the Ethereal Plane, any vertical movement does not impose a movement penalty.

optionalfeature.name: Visions of Death
entries: While using Ethereal Shift, you can replace an attack you make with an attempt to {@condition Frightened|XPHB} a creature within 60 feet of you that you can see.

The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On failure, it becomes {@condition Frightened|XPHB} and takes 3 rolls of your Hunter's Die as damage on a failure. On a successful saving throw, it takes half as much damage and is not {@condition Frightened|XPHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Ethereal Step
entries: Once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, you can cast the {@spell Etherealness|XPHB} spell on yourself as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}. When cast this way, the spell lasts until the start of your next turn.
If you have already used this feature, you can use it again at the cost of 4 Instinct.

optionalfeature.name: Halfway There
entries: When an attack would reduce you to zero hit points, you can make a Wisdom saving throw with a DC equal to 5 plus the damage taken. On a success, you are reduced to one hit point instead of zero. You can do this once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}.
You have advantage on Death saving throws.

optionalfeature.name: Hunter of People
entries: You are trained to find people, no matter where they are hiding. You can add your Hunter's Die to ability checks using the {@skill Intimidation|XPHB}, {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}, {@skill Insight|XPHB} or {@skill Deception|XPHB} skills that are made to gain information from others.

optionalfeature.name: Favoured Terrain: City
entries: You do your best work where people are. In cities and other settlements, you have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks, you cannot become lost outside of magical means, {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} does not slow your travel, and you can find enough food to eat no matter where you are.
Furthermore, you have advantage on ability checks made to identify local customs and find secret or hidden pathways in the environment.

optionalfeature.name: Building Scaler
entries: You are practised climbing buildings and leaping between them. You have a climbing speed equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} and your jump distance is doubled.

optionalfeature.name: Dirty Fighting
